Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Microelectrode Array Sensors for SARS-CoV-2 and Other RNA Viruses
Award.AbstractNarration: There is an urgent need for accurate measurement tools to test for the presence of the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 in samples, so that this information may be used for diagnosing the novel coronavirus infectious disease 2019 (COVID-19). Obtaining test results on the timeline of minutes is essential to limiting spread of the virus and helping individuals and communities make appropriate decisions. Alarmingly high rates of missed virus presence (false negatives) have been found using some of the current fast testing routes. Those routes typically rely on sample amplification that is time-consuming and resource-intensive, and due to their complicated multi-step sample treatments, those routes are more likely to generate false negatives. The immediate goal of this project, led by Dr. Gangli Wang and colleagues at Georgia State University, is to design and develop electrochemical sensors whose "switched-on" response to SARS-CoV-2 presence results from target interactions with specific chemical species in the nucleic acids of the virus. The response is rapidly intensified to allow for trace-level detection of virus, potentially within minutes. The design principle provides several benefits, such as drastically simplified sample pretreatment, fast turn-around time, and simplified one-step detection with greatly decreased false negative outcomes. These essential qualities pave the way for future point-of-use applications that go beyond SARS-CoV-2. The project provides a rare opportunity for fundamental measurement science to address an ongoing societal and global crisis through cutting-edge research. In addition, the project provides a rich and diverse educational experience for students and postdoctoral fellows at Georgia State University, an institution with large numbers of minority students and students from low-income backgrounds. Scientific concepts and results are disseminated through classroom teaching, local events, attendance at scientific meetings, and publications. Additional educational and outreach activities provide opportunities to many in the Atlanta Metro Area and beyond through an on-going NSF undergraduate research program and the Atlanta Science Festival, as well as several other recently established mentor programs at Georgia State University. <br/><br/>The enabling intellectual merit is the in-situ signal amplification mechanism in signal-on electrochemical sensors via redox cycling. The novel design drastically improves the lower limit of detection (LoD) to be competitive with and possibly surpass that of existing methods and eliminates the need for error-prone, multi-step sample treatments, such as enrichment, labeling, or amplification. The concept, employed in single-entity electrochemistry, is fundamentally different from the sample amplification strategy adopted in most nucleic acid analysis tools being used. In principle, the LoD is anticipated to approach utmost levels, i.e., single copies of ribonucleic acid (RNA) where the response time is correlated through statistical analysis. The sensor specificity to the SARS-CoV-2 specific RNA sequence(s) is based on their recognition by electrode-immobilized probes. With key components pre-assembled as integral parts of the sensor, near-zero background may be established, which is the prerequisite to improve the LoD and resolve binding of single nucleic acids. Binding with the target sequence turns on the designed electron-transfer pathway: the redox molecule on the recognition probe is then abled to repeatedly mediate electron transfers between the sensor electrode and the co-reactants in solution. The signal-on mechanism further mitigates nonspecific adsorption concerns. Individual sensors are assembled into arrays to simultaneously detect multiple target RNAs. The multiplex signal readout design represents another intellectual merit for enhanced sensor performance. The mechanistic insights from cyclic voltammetry and low LoD achieved with pulse voltammetry are envisioned as critical for the formulation of optimal and generalizable measurement methods and protocols. Synthetic samples, common biomatrices, viral RNA extractions, and virus-infected cell lysates are selected to establish calibration profiles and detection strategies. Comparison of the results with those from laboratory analysis techniques, such as reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction, provides further validation of the sensor efficacy. In addition to offering qualitative Yes/No answers for fast testing, the sensor approach may provide quantitative information in absolute concentrations over a wide dynamic range, an outcome of great value to the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as to other on-going and future needs in the biological sensing community.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID19 pandemic has disrupted the healthcare systems and the living norms across the world for over one year. An essential step to control the pandemic is to detect the new coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and its mutation variants accurately and timely. Laboratory analysis based on reverse transcription PCR techniques are available but with limited capacity to meet the demand. Various fast-testing tools have been introduced under FDA emergency use authorization. Almost all those test methods, however, share two common features: 1. requiring sample amplification and multi-step treatments and 2. providing qualitative answers in positive/negative, i.e. whether a tested sample contains virus or not. Sample amplifications along with multi-step sample treatments are time-consuming and resource-intensive, and more detrimentally likely to induce false test results. There are widely recognized problems in that false negative results would cause further virus spread, and false positives would incur unnecessary sacrifice in productivity and quality of life. Quantitative information is critical for SARS-CoV2 related biomedical research as well as policy making, but remains scarce. With the funding support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Chemistry Division at NSF, this RAPID project has 1. established a new signal-on microelectrode sensor platform to amplify the detection signal and eliminated the need to amplify viral RNAs; 2. developed a multi-parameter kinetics-based calibration strategy to improve detection accuracy and specificity; and 3. achieved a lower limit of detection of zeptomolar within minutes in one-step analysis using prototype devices. These research progresses are achieved through collective hard work of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows together with the principle and co-investigators. With in-person education resumed and the media reports, the project has and will continue to positively impact the large numbers of minority students and students from low-income backgrounds at Georgia State University.

The fundamental principles of 1. the in-situ signal amplification and 2. kinetics-based multi-parameter calibration are developed using electrochemical detection platforms. Gold microelectrodes are functionalized with designed nucleic acid probes that recognize specifically with the target RNA sequence/s. In the absence of the target viral RNAs, the recognition probes self fold into short loop structures and disconnect electron transfer pathways. Insignificant baseline current, i.e., background/noise, enables the detection of low signals or low abundance analyte. A signal-on mechanism is enabled through the binding with the target RNA sequence which turns on the electron transduction pathway. Redox cycling, which is widely used in single entity electrochemistry, further enhances the detection signal. Multi-parameter calibrations readily discriminate nonspecific interference, a common problem in sensor/assay development, because of the differences in the thermodynamics in the interaction which change the signaling kinetics. With pulse voltammetry technique readout, zepto-molar synthetic pure target sequences have been detected with a wide dynamic range up to nano-molar (that can be further enhanced if needed). The prototype sensors have been challenged with real life samples, including those prior to PCR analysis and the lysates of various origin without purifications. The results have been disseminated through classroom teaching, research mentoring, presentations at scientific meetings, and publications on professional journals. A prior patent application related to this methodology has been granted and technology transfer efforts are underway.
